raw_text:
Dallaglio his own man to the end
 
 Controversy and Lawrence Dallaglio have never been very far away from each other throughout a glittering international career.
 
 Even the end of his nine-year career came out of the blue, just four days before the start of the season. But then Dallaglio has always been his own man. Ever since emerging onto the international scene Dallaglio has polarised opinions. To supporters of England, Dallaglio could do no wrong. An integral part of a sustained period of success for England, Dallaglio's crowning glory was his part in the side that won the Rugby World Cup in 2003.
 
 Rival fans, meanwhile, have tended to take an alternative view, seeing Dallaglio as the epitome of the less agreeable characteristics of English rugby. Never afraid to speak his mind, be it to the referee or the opposition on the pitch, or his coach or the media off it, Dallaglio has sometimes rubbed people up the wrong way. Dallaglio arrived as part of the unheralded England side which became the shock winners of the first Rugby Sevens World Cup in 1993. It took him another two years to graduate to the full England XV, but once there he proved to the manor born. Displaying maturity and physical power beyond his years, Dallaglio rapidly established himself as an automatic choice able to play any one of the three back-row positions at international standard.
 
 Within two years of his debut, Dallaglio was offered the England captain's band, and his career continued to go from strength to strength as he made the 1997 Lions tour to South Africa. Although overlooked for the captaincy in favour of England team-mate Martin Johnson, he played a massive role in the 2-1 series victory. But after building up a seemingly unstoppable momentum, Dallaglio's career hit the buffers at speed in 1999.
 
 First came the last-minute defeat to Wales in which Dallaglio's decision not to kick for goal in the dying minutes was blamed for costing England a Grand Slam. Worse was to follow though as an infamous newspaper sting cost him his treasured England captaincy. With sensational allegations of drug use - of which he was subsequently cleared - splashed across the front pages, a devastated Dallaglio stepped down as England skipper. But he bounced back, getting his head down at club level before returning to the England fold, albeit now as a lieutenant to new captain Johnson. As a member of a new-look England side on the long road to World Cup glory - a journey not without mishaps as a succession of Grand Slams opportunities were spurned - Dallaglio emerged as a key performer once again.
 
 Yet another setback arrived in 2001 as a serious knee injury cut short Dallaglio's involvement on the Lions tour to Australia.
 
 Rumours began to circulate that his career was over but, in typical Dallaglio style, he embarked on a punishing schedule of rehabilitation to return an even more fearsome physical specimen. One effect of the injury was to rob Dallaglio of much of his pace, but ever the pragmatist, he reinvented himself as a close quarters number eight of the highest calibre.
 
 The only player to play every minute of England's World Cup triumph in Australia, Dallaglio could hardly have done more to secure England's historic win, and for that he will always be held in the highest esteem by England supporters. Following Johnson's retirement, Dallaglio's career came full circle as Woodward restored him as England captain. While England did not hit the heights in Dallaglio's second spell as captain, losing five of their eight post-World Cup Tests, Dallaglio led by example, leaving him as one of the few members of a squad lacking many World Cup stars to live up to expectations. Dallaglio walks away from the international game safe in the knowledge that he will go down as one of England's most accomplished players, if not one of the great captains despite his evident pride in leading his country.
 
 The problem now for England is how to replace the almost irreplaceable. The likes of Matt Dawson, Jonny Wilkinson, Phil Vickery and Hill have all been mentioned as contenders for Dallaglio's role as captain. But it is as a player that England will really struggle to replace the 32-year-old. Although players like Joe Worsley and Chris Jones are more than capable of stepping up, the fact that there is no stand-out candidate speaks volumes about Dallaglio's massive influence on English rugby.
llama3.2:1b: Dallaglio served as England's captain for a short time, stepping down after a series of controversies and setbacks, including an infamous newspaper sting in 2001.
He was the epitome of polarizing opinions throughout his career due to his outspoken nature, both on and off the pitch.
His playing style involved being part of successful teams such as the England XV which won the Rugby World Cup in 2003 and the Sevens World Cup in 1993.
Dallaglio's career was marked by various highs and lows including a major setback with a serious knee injury that cut short his involvement on the Lions tour to Australia.
llama3.2:3b: Lawrence Dallaglio polarized opinions throughout his glittering international career, with supporters admiring his success and critics labeling him as disagreeable.
He emerged from an unheralded England side to win the Rugby World Cup in 2003.
Despite controversy surrounding his career, including a treasured captaincy being stripped due to allegations of drug use, Dallaglio bounced back and played a key role in England's success.
He lost his pace due to injury but adapted as a close-quarters number eight.
After a second stint as England captain, Dallaglio will be remembered as one of England's most accomplished players despite not being considered among the great captains.
gemma2:2b: Lawrence Dallaglio was a polarizing figure in rugby who enjoyed both immense success and controversy throughout his career.
He captained England to World Cup victory and held the coveted captaincy position for several years.
Despite setbacks such as injuries and allegations of drug use, he remained resilient and returned to lead England once more, proving his enduring impact on the sport.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Dallaglio's career was marked by a long journey from the international scene to becoming England's captain for the 2003 Rugby World Cup.
Despite initial doubts and criticisms, he proved an invaluable asset as the England team won the tournament.
He displayed his physical prowess on the field and quickly established himself as one of the most reliable players in England's squad.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Lawrence Dallaglio struggled for England as captain but remains one of the greatest captains in national team history due to his impact on both international and domestic performance.
qwen2.5:3b: Dallaglio faced controversy throughout his international career but remained a polarising figure, beloved by England supporters for his contributions to success and detested by rivals who criticized his outspoken nature.
He emerged from an underdog position in the Rugby Sevens World Cup to become a key player, eventually earning the captaincy before losing it due to a controversial drug scandal.
His subsequent return was marked by another successful Lions tour.
Dallaglio's final World Cup victory cemented his status as one of England's greatest players, though his retirement left a void in leadership roles that is difficult to fill.
opencoder:1.5b: "Dallaglio was his own man, a decisive player who had won a series of international matches.
Despite his rigorous training and dedication to formulating tough performances, he managed to turn the tide when England took the lead in the 19th World Cup.
Despite many challenges, Dallaglio's decision not to kick the ball for goal was the only way to save England from being knocked out by Wales.
But after losing all but two of his matches, he embarked on a new journey, replacing himself as England captain."
smollm:1.7b: The controversy surrounding Dallaglio's career has been intense, with many fans feeling that he was unfairly maligned by the media and his peers.
However, it is important to remember that Dallaglio's success in international rugby was not solely due to his own actions or decisions as a player.

Rather, it was largely due to the support of England's top coaches, including Phil Vickery and Jonny Wilkinson, who have been instrumental in helping him develop into one of the greatest players of all time.
Despite his impressive career record, Dallaglio has faced criticism from some quarters for not being more vocal about his own personal life or taking a stronger stance on social issues.

However, it is important to remember that Dallaglio's decision to step down as captain in 2001 was largely due to the fact that he was struggling with health problems and was unable to continue playing at the highest level.
Overall, while there are certainly other talented players who could have filled Dallaglio's shoes as captain, it is clear that his influence on English rugby cannot be overstated.
He has been a constant presence throughout his career, providing inspiration and motivation to his teammates and fans alike.
As such, he should be given the opportunity to take on the role of captain in 2019-2023, rather than being passed over by other contenders.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: DALLAGLIO excelled in international rugby, building a successful career while facing criticism for not kicking for England.
After supporting the team that won the Rugby World Cup in 2003, he was seen as reliable by his coach and later rebuilt physically.
Despite his success, England did not win the World Cup again, and DALLAGLIO remained in charge when Johnson retired.
England is seeking a replacement and mentions players like Dawson and Wilkinson as potential candidates.
However, no clear standout candidate emerges from this dynamic.
tinyllama:1.1b: Dallaglio his own man to the end, even during a shocking period of success for England, he polarized opinions.

Rivals fans believed Dallaglio was notorious for his less agreeable characteristics, while rivals also took issue with him playing the role of captain during England's unexpected victory in South Africa in 1993.

His subsequent career saw him move from the 1997 Lion's tour to South Africa to the Grand Slams, but after a last-minute defeat, his captaincy was brought into question and he was eventually sacked by England coach Martin Johnson.

Despite losing five of their post-World Cup Tests, Dallaglio led by example as England captain and remains an iconic figure in English rugby despite lacking many World Cup stars to live up to expectations.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Dallaglio was a legendary rugby player who enjoyed an illustrious career, playing for England in several landmark matches throughout his international career.
Although he was known for his fierce competitiveness and physicality, it was also clear that he could also play with a maturity and intelligence that allowed him to excel at the international stage.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses Lawrence Dallaglio's impact on English rugby as a player and captain.
He started his international career in 1994 and was known for polarizing opinions among supporters due to his outspoken nature.
He played a significant role in England's success, including their Rugby World Cup win in 2003.
However, he faced setbacks, such as being removed from the captaincy following an alleged drug scandal.
Despite this, Dallaglio returned to the national team and led them to more victories.
He was also involved in the Lions tour to Australia but had a knee injury that affected his playing style.
Dallaglio's career was cut short by another injury, but he continued to play with rehabilitation and became an integral part of the team.
His leadership abilities were showcased when he regained his captaincy after the retirement of the previous captain.
However, England struggled without World Cup stars in their lineup.
The problem now is finding a player who can replace Dallaglio's significant impact on English rugby.
orca-mini:3b: Dallaglio was his own man to the end of his nine-year career, which came to an end just four days before the start of the season.

Although he never had a conventional career path, he emerged as an automatic choice for the England team at international standard and played a massive role in the 2-1 series victory during the Lions tour to South Africa in 1997.
Dallaglio was hailed as one of the most accomplished players in English rugby history, but his impact on the game goes beyond just his own achievements.
He led by example as England captain following Martin Johnson's retirement, and he will always be held in the highest esteem by England supporters.
While there is no clear successor to Dallaglio as captain, the likes of Matt Dawson, Jonny Wilkinson, Phil Vickery, and Hill are contenders for the role.
However, it remains to be seen whether England can replace Dallaglio's influence on the team.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Lawrence Dallaglio, a polarizing figure in international rugby, had an illustrious nine-year career as a British player for England.
Known for his maturity, physical prowess, and versatility as a back-rower, Dallaglio was instrumental in several achievements, including the 2003 Rugby World Cup win.
Despite initial skepticism from some fans due to his assertive on-field personality, he became an integral part of successful teams.
His career was marked by setbacks, such as the Wales defeat in 1999 and a drug scandal that led to his captaincy loss.
Dallaglio overcame these challenges through perseverance and rehabilitation after a serious knee injury during the Lions tour to Australia in 2001.
He emerged as an exceptional number eight, playing every minute of England's World Cup victory in Australia.
Following Johnson's retirement, Dallaglio briefly reclaimed the captaincy but led a team that lost five out of eight post-World Cup Tests.
Regardless of his performance as captain, Dallaglio is considered one of England's most accomplished players and a crucial figure in their history.
Replacing him presents a significant challenge for the national team due to his all-around contributions and lack of standout successors.
